section.title: Enabling TLS for MySQL Traffic
section.para: MySQL traffic can be encrypted using TLS. For completely new &kw-hos; deployments using the supplied input model example files, you will have to uncomment the commented entries for tls-component-endpoints:. For upgrades from a previous version, you will have to add the entries to your input model files if you have not already done so. This topic explains how to do both.

section.title: Enabling TLS on the database server for client access

step.para: Edit network_groups.yml to either add mysql under tls-component-endpoints in your existing file from a previous version, or uncomment it if installing from scratch.
After making the necessary changes, commit the changed file to git and run the config-processor-run and reconfigure Ansible playbooks:
step.screen: cd ~/openstack git add -A git commit -m "My changed config" cd ~/openstack/ardana/ansible/ ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost config-processor-run.yml -e encrypt="<encryption key>" -e rekey="" ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost ready-deployment.yml cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/ardana/ansible

or ardana-reconfigure if you are reconfiguring an existing one:

section.title: MySQL replication over TLS
section.para: MySQL replication over TLS is disabled. This is true even if you followed the instruction to turn on Mysql TLS in the previous section. Those steps turn on the service interactions to the database.

para.emphasis: Turning on MySQL replication over TLS

note.para: Using TLS connections for MySQL replication will incur a performance cost.

section.para: You should have already enabled TLS for MySQL client interactions in the previous section. If not, read .
TLS for MySQL replication is not turned on by default. Therefore, you will need to follow a manual process. Again, the steps are different for new systems and upgrades.

section.title: Enabling TLS for MySQL replication on a new deployment

step.para: Log in to the &clm; node and before running the config processor, edit the ~/openstack/my_cloud/config/mariadb/defaults.yml file.
Search for mysql_gcomms_bind_tls. You should find this section:
step.screen: # TLS disabled for cluster #mysql_gcomms_bind_tls: "{{ host.bind['FND_MDB'].mysql_gcomms.tls }}" mysql_gcomms_bind_tls: False

step.para: Uncomment the appropriate line so the file looks like this:
step.screen: # TLS disabled for cluster mysql_gcomms_bind_tls: "{{ host.bind['FND_MDB'].mysql_gcomms.tls }}" #mysql_gcomms_bind_tls: False

step.para: Follow the steps to deploy or reconfigure your cloud: in .

section.title: Enabling TLS for MySQL replication on an existing system
section.para: If your cluster is already up, perform these steps to enable MySQL replication over TLS:

step.para: Edit the following two files: ~/openstack/my_cloud/config/mariadb/defaults.yml and ~/scratch/ansible/next/ardana/ansible/roles/FND-MDB/defaults/main.yml. Note that these files are identical. The first is a master file and the second is a scratch version that is used for the current deployment. Make the same changes as explained in .

After this your MySQL should come up and replicate over TLS. You need to follow this section again if you ever want to switch TLS off for MySQL replication. You also must repeat these steps if any lifecycle operation changes the mysql_gcomms_bind_tls option.

section.title: Testing whether a service is using TLS
section.para: Almost all services that have a database are able to communicate over TLS. You can test whether a service, in this example the Identity service (Keystone), is communicating with MySQL over TLS by executing the following steps:

listitem.para: Log into the &clm; as root and run the mysql command.
Type 'help;' or '\h' for help. Type '\c' to clear the current input statement.

listitem.screen: mysql> select * from information_schema.user_statistics where user='keystone'\G

listitem.para: Note the results. TOTAL_SSL_CONNECTIONS should not be zero:
